trustfund:
TF039354-ZAMBIA - PUBLIC SECTOR REFORM

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated satisfactory, and project sustainability is rated as
            likely. Both World Bank and Borrower performances were rated
            overall satisfactory. However, viewed in the context of the
            entire reform program of the 1990's, the costly delays
            in privatizing the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM)
            make Borrower rating unsatisfactory. Lessons learned include
            the following: Dealing with deep-seated problems of weak
            technical and managerial capacity and governance such as
            those faced by Zambia requires operations that combine
            sectoral focus and technical assistance/institution building
            features, longer time horizons and quick disbursements.
            Timing and strategy of privatization should be geared to
            country circumstances; the implicit privatization strategy
            followed here was to pursue the smaller, less controverisal
            privatizations first, leaving the technically and
            politically difficult, but more meaningful privatizations
            earlier. Policy advice and conditionality involving trade
            reform should consider the regional context. Because its
            main regional trading partners lagged in their trade reform,
            the benefits of Zambia's own trade reforms were
            limited, relative to the high fiscal costs. Given existing
            weaknesses of budgetary procedures and processes, specifying
            budget allocations for social sector ministries and programs
            will not ensure that funds are received by the ministries or
            spent for purposes intended.
